item.title: Nordic aliens
item.description:
Alleged humanoid extraterrestrials ðŸ”—

This entry focuses on “Nordics,” “Nordic aliens,” or “Tall Whites,” which are names given in ufology to humanoid races purportedly from the Pleiades star cluster. These beings are described as resembling Nordic, Germanic, or Scandinavian humans, with features like tall stature (6-7 ft), blond hair, blue eyes, and fair skin. Some accounts mention pale-blue/grey or pastel purple skin tones. George Adamski is noted as one of the first to report contact with these beings in the 1950s. The mythology surrounding them often includes telepathy, benevolence, and physical beauty.

History ðŸ”—

This section discusses the historical context and cultural influences related to the Nordic alien phenomenon. David J. Skal suggests that the 1951 film The Day the Earth Stood Still may have inspired early stories. Stephanie Kelley-Romano describes alien abduction beliefs as a “living myth,” associating Nordic aliens with spiritual growth and protection. These aliens are often portrayed as benevolent beings concerned with Earth’s ecology and world peace, possessing telepathic powers and described as paternal and youthful. While popular in the 1950s, claims of encounters became less common as the grey alien archetype rose to prominence.

Publications by those claiming to have been contacted ðŸ”—

This section lists books written by individuals who claim to have had personal contact with Nordic aliens. These include Flying Saucers Have Landed and Inside the Space Ships by George Adamski, From Outer Space to You by Howard Menger, The Walton Experience by Travis Walton, and Millennial Hospitality by Charles James Hall (adapted into the film Walking with the Tall Whites). The UFO religion Universe People also publishes interactions as “Talks with Teachings from my Cosmic Friends.”

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of related topics and figures in ufology, including:

  • Space Brothers
  • Truman Bethurum
  • Elizabeth Klarer
  • Billy Meier
  • Linda Moulton Howe
  • List of alleged extraterrestrial beings
  • Star people (New Age)
  • Arcturians (New Age)
  • UFOs
  • UFO religion

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books and academic papers.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to Wikimedia Commons for media related to Nordic aliens.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nordic_aliens

item.title: Extraterrestrial life
item.description:
Extraterrestrial Life ðŸ”—

Extraterrestrial life, also known as alien life, refers to life that originates from a world other than Earth. While no conclusive scientific detection has occurred, the possibilities range from simple prokaryotes to intelligent beings and advanced civilizations. The field dedicated to its study is astrobiology.

Context ðŸ”—

This section provides background information on the conditions necessary for life in the universe. It starts with the Big Bang and the subsequent cooling of the universe, highlighting the initial lack of elements necessary for life. The formation of carbon and oxygen through stellar fusion is mentioned, as well as the emergence of planetary systems and organic compounds. Abiogenesis and panspermia are presented as potential origins of life. The section also discusses the vastness of the universe, the limitations of current space exploration technology, and the concept of the circumstellar habitable zone (Goldilocks zone). It concludes by noting the potential for past extraterrestrial life and the adaptive capabilities of life on Earth, while emphasizing that habitability does not guarantee the existence of life. Avi Loeb is mentioned for his speculation on the “Habitable Epoch of the Early Universe”.

Likelihood of Existence ðŸ”—

This section explores the debate on whether extraterrestrial life is common or rare. It presents the argument for ubiquitous life based on the size and age of the universe, the abundance of life’s chemical elements, and the universality of physical laws, citing Carl Sagan and Stephen Hawking. The Copernican and mediocrity principles are also mentioned. The Rare Earth hypothesis, which posits that a unique combination of factors makes Earth habitable, is presented as a counterargument. The Drake equation, devised by Frank Drake, is introduced as a probabilistic argument to estimate the number of communicative extraterrestrial civilizations in the Milky Way galaxy. The section concludes by discussing the Fermi paradox, which highlights the contradiction between the high probability estimates of extraterrestrial civilizations and the lack of evidence for their existence. Dennis W. Sciama, Zhi-Wei Wang, and Samuel L. Braunstein are mentioned in relation to the Fermi paradox.

Biochemical Basis ðŸ”—

This section discusses the potential biochemical characteristics of extraterrestrial life. It considers a range of lifeforms from microorganisms to intelligent beings. Non-equilibrium thermodynamics, stars, volcanoes, plate tectonics, and hydrothermal vents are presented as potential energy sources. Water is highlighted as a crucial solvent, though alternatives like ammonia and hydrocarbons are mentioned. The section explores the chemical elements that could compose extraterrestrial life, focusing on carbon and its potential replacements like silicon. The advantages and disadvantages of silicon-based life are discussed. Norman Horowitz is mentioned for his views on carbon-based life. The section also considers the potential for radically different biochemistries, the role of natural selection, and the likelihood of cell membranes. The evolution from simple cells to multicellular organisms is discussed, with Simon Conway Morris’s views on convergent evolution mentioned. Scientists from the University of Oxford are mentioned for their study suggesting aliens may be similar to humans.

Harsh Environmental Conditions on Earth Harboring Life ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the origins of life on Earth and how it may be related to the possibility of extraterrestrial life. It highlights that the conditions on other planets seem too extreme to harbor life, but some of the earliest and most basic forms of life on Earth originated in extreme environments. Fossil evidence and historical theories have marked environments like hydrothermal vents or acidic hot springs as some of the first places that life could have originated on Earth. The aspects of these harsh environments that make them ideal for the origin of life on Earth, as well as the possibility of creation of life on other planets, is the chemical reactions forming spontaneously.

Planetary Habitability in the Solar System ðŸ”—

This section examines the potential for life on other bodies within our solar system. Mars, Europa, and Enceladus are identified as the most likely candidates. Venus is discussed as a terrestrial planet that may have once been similar to Earth. The possibility of microbial life in Venus’s high-altitude clouds is mentioned. Mars is described as a cold, airless desert, but with evidence of past abundant water. The potential for ancient fossilized remains and surviving microbes underground is noted. The gas giants and ice giants are deemed unlikely to contain life, but the possibility of life on moons orbiting these planets is explored. Europa’s subsurface ocean is highlighted, as well as Ganymede and Callisto. Enceladus’s eruption columns are mentioned as a potential source of study. Titan is presented as the only celestial body besides Earth with liquid bodies on the surface, with speculations about lifeforms with different biochemistry.

Scientific Search ðŸ”—

This section outlines the scientific methods used to search for extraterrestrial life. Astrobiology is defined as the science that studies life in the universe. The search is carried out both directly and indirectly, with the identification of exoplanets being a key component. The section mentions the number of identified exoplanets and systems as of September 2017 and February 2021.

Search for Basic Life ðŸ”—

This section details the search for biosignatures within the solar system and beyond. It mentions the study of planetary surfaces, meteorites, and telescope data. The controversial report of nanobacteria-like structures in the ALH84001 meteorite is discussed. The Viking Mars landers’ gas emission experiments are mentioned, along with the methane signatures found in Mars’s atmosphere. NASA scientists Carol Stoker and Larry Lemke are mentioned in this context. The Mars Science Laboratory and the Curiosity rover are highlighted as tools for assessing past and present habitability on Mars. A group of scientists at Cornell University are mentioned for starting a catalog of microorganisms, with the way each one reacts to sunlight. NASA’s study of meteorites found on Antarctica is mentioned, with the discovery of adenine, guanine, hypoxanthine, and xanthine. Scientists reported that cosmic dust contains complex organic compounds. Astronomers at Copenhagen University reported the detection of glycolaldehyde in a distant star system. Astronomers reported the first time discovery, in the plumes of Enceladus, moon of the planet Saturn, of hydrogen cyanide.

Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligences ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the search for extraterrestrial intelligence through technosignatures. Interstellar communications, atmospheric effects, and planetary-sized structures like Dyson spheres are mentioned as potential indicators. Organizations like the SETI Institute are searching for radio waves and laser pulses. The use of artificial intelligence in this search is mentioned. The section also discusses the potential for detecting nitrogen dioxide, chlorofluorocarbons, and light pollution in exoplanet atmospheres. The Kardashev scale is introduced as a measure of a civilization’s energy consumption.

Extrasolar Planets ðŸ”—

This section discusses the search for exoplanets that may be conducive to life, focusing on terrestrial planets within habitable zones. The number of exoplanets discovered is mentioned, along with the Kepler space telescope’s contributions. The section notes that there is at least one planet on average per star, and that about 1 in 5 Sun-like stars have an Earth-sized planet in the habitable zone. Proxima Centauri b is mentioned as the nearest known exoplanet. The least massive and most massive exoplanets known are mentioned. The section concludes by noting the importance of planetary habitability in determining the suitability of a planet for hosting life.

History and Cultural Impact ðŸ”—

This section explores the historical and cultural context of the search for extraterrestrial life.

Cosmic Pluralism ðŸ”—

This section traces the historical development of the idea of cosmic pluralism, the belief in numerous inhabited worlds beyond Earth. It begins with the Ancient Greeks, contrasting the atomist view of Epicurus with the Aristotelian view. Medieval Muslim writers Fakhr al-Din al-Razi and Muhammad al-Baqir are mentioned for supporting cosmic pluralism based on the Qur’an. Chaucer’s poem The House of Fame is mentioned. The section also discusses the association of atomism with atheism and the varying views within the Church. Anaxagoras is mentioned for the term ‘panspermia’.

Early Modern Period ðŸ”—

This section discusses the impact of the Copernican Revolution and the invention of the telescope on the concept of extraterrestrial life. Nicolaus Copernicus, Tycho Brahe, Johannes Kepler, and Galileo Galilei are mentioned for their contributions to the heliocentric model. Galileo’s trial for heresy is noted. Giordano Bruno is highlighted as an early proponent of extraterrestrial life, who was tried and executed for his beliefs. Isaac Newton’s theory of gravity is mentioned as further strengthening the heliocentric model.

19th Century ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the 19th-century speculation about life on Mars, fueled by telescopic observations of apparent Martian canals. Percival Lowell is mentioned for his books proposing that the canals were the work of a civilization. William Wallace Campbell is mentioned for his spectroscopic analysis of Mars’s atmosphere. Louis Pasteur’s disproving of spontaneous generation is noted. JÃ¶ns Jacob Berzelius, Kelvin, Hermann von Helmholtz, and Svante Arrhenius are mentioned for their panspermia theory. The development of science fiction is mentioned.

Recent History ðŸ”—

This section discusses the emergence of astrobiology as a distinct science. NASA, ESA, and INAF are mentioned as organizations studying astrobiology. The limitations of studying only Earth-based life are noted. The rise of pseudoscience, such as ufology and ancient astronauts, is mentioned. Lewis White Beck is mentioned for tracing the evolution of philosophical thought. The section concludes by noting the advances in planetary habitability knowledge, astronomy, and spacecraft technology. Frank Drake and Jacques Monod are mentioned. Peter Ward and Donald Brownlee are mentioned for their book Rare Earth: Why Complex Life is Uncommon in the Universe.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_life

item.title: Ancient astronauts
item.description:
Ancient Astronauts ðŸ”—

Ancient astronauts, also known as ancient aliens, is a pseudoscientific belief that intelligent extraterrestrial beings visited Earth in ancient times and influenced the development of human civilization. Proponents suggest that these aliens affected cultures, technologies, religions, and even human biology. A common idea is that deities in various religions were actually extraterrestrials, and their advanced technologies were seen as divine powers by early humans. Academics and archaeologists dismiss these claims as pseudoarchaeology and unscientific, lacking credible peer-reviewed evidence. Some argue that these theories have racist undertones, diminishing the achievements of indigenous cultures.

Key Points:

  • Extraterrestrial contact in ancient times
  • Influence on human civilization
  • Deities as extraterrestrials
  • Dismissal by academics as pseudoscience
  • Potential racist implications

Important People:

  • Robert Charroux
  • Jacques Bergier
  • Jean Sendy
  • Erich von DÃ¤niken
  • Alexander Kazantsev
  • Zecharia Sitchin
  • Robert K. G. Temple
  • Giorgio A. Tsoukalos
  • David Hatcher Childress
  • Peter Kolosimo
  • Mauro Biglino

Overview ðŸ”—

Various terms are used to describe claims about ancient astronauts, including ancient aliens, ancient ufonauts, ancient space pilots, paleocontact, astronaut- or alien gods, and paleo- or biblical-SETI. Believers often assert that humans are descendants or creations of extraterrestrial intelligence that landed on Earth in the distant past. They propose that human knowledge, religion, and culture originated from these ancient alien visitors, who acted as a “mother culture.” Additionally, they claim that extraterrestrials built or assisted in building structures like the Egyptian pyramids and the Moai stone heads of Easter Island. Proponents cite documentary gaps in historical and archaeological records and point to archaeological artifacts they consider anachronistic and beyond the technical capabilities of ancient people. These artifacts, sometimes called “out-of-place artifacts,” include artwork and legends reinterpreted to support extraterrestrial contact or technologies.

Key Points:

  • Alternative terms for ancient astronaut theories
  • Humans as descendants or creations of extraterrestrials
  • Extraterrestrial origin of human knowledge and culture
  • Extraterrestrial involvement in building ancient structures
  • Use of “out-of-place artifacts” as evidence

History of Ancient Aliens Beliefs and Their Proponents ðŸ”—

Paleocontact narratives first appeared in early science fiction in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Harold T. Wilkins proposed the idea in earnest in 1954. It gained popularity in the 1960s due to the Space Race and the success of Erich von DÃ¤niken’s works. Critics emerged in the 1970s, discrediting Von DÃ¤niken’s claims. By the early 1980s, the idea had little remaining support.

Key Points:

  • Origins in early science fiction
  • Rise in popularity in the 1960s
  • Criticism and decline in the 1970s and 1980s

Shklovskii and Sagan ðŸ”—

Carl Sagan co-authored Intelligent Life in the Universe with Soviet astrophysicist Iosif Shklovsky in 1966. Sagan later expressed disapproval of writers like von DÃ¤niken who treated speculations about ancient astronauts as valid evidence. Sagan acknowledged the possibility of extraterrestrial visits but emphasized that they were unproven and improbable.

Key Points:

  • Sagan and Shklovsky’s influence on ancient astronaut theories
  • Sagan’s disapproval of uncritical writers
  • Emphasis on the lack of evidence for extraterrestrial visits

Erich von DÃ¤niken ðŸ”—

Erich von DÃ¤niken became a leading proponent of the ancient astronaut hypothesis in the late 1960s and early 1970s with his book Chariots of the Gods? He argued that certain artifacts required more advanced technology than was available to ancient cultures, suggesting they were constructed by extraterrestrials or humans who learned from them. These artifacts include Stonehenge, Pumapunku, the Moai of Easter Island, the Great Pyramid of Giza, and the ancient Baghdad electric batteries. Von DÃ¤niken interpreted ancient art and iconography as illustrations of air and space vehicles, non-human creatures, and advanced technology. He also suggested that geographically separated cultures shared artistic themes, implying a common extraterrestrial origin. He interpreted the sarcophagus lid of Maya ruler Pacal the Great as depicting an astronaut. He viewed the origins of many religions as reactions to encounters with an alien race, with humans considering alien technology supernatural and the aliens themselves as gods.

Key Points:

  • Von DÃ¤niken’s role as a leading proponent
  • Argument that certain artifacts required advanced technology
  • Interpretation of ancient art as evidence of extraterrestrial contact
  • View of religions as reactions to alien encounters

Important People:

  • Erich von DÃ¤niken

Locations:

  • Stonehenge
  • Pumapunku
  • Easter Island
  • Great Pyramid of Giza
  • Baghdad

Zecharia Sitchin ðŸ”—

Zecharia Sitchin’s The Earth Chronicles series revolves around his interpretation of ancient Sumerian and Middle Eastern texts, megalithic sites, and artifacts. He hypothesized that the gods of ancient Mesopotamia were astronauts from the planet Nibiru, which he claimed the Sumerians believed to be a remote “12th planet.” Sitchin argued that Sumerian texts tell the story of the Anunnaki, inhabitants of Nibiru, who came to Earth approximately 400,000 years ago to mine raw materials, especially gold. They genetically engineered laborers, creating Homo sapiens sapiens, the Adapa or Adam of later mythology.

Key Points:

  • Sitchin’s interpretation of Sumerian texts
  • Hypothesis of the Anunnaki from Nibiru
  • Genetic engineering of humans by the Anunnaki

Important People:

  • Zecharia Sitchin

Locations:

  • Mesopotamia

Robert Temple ðŸ”—

Robert K. G. Temple’s 1976 book, The Sirius Mystery, argues that the Dogon people of northwestern Mali preserved an account of extraterrestrial visitation from around 5,000 years ago. He cited advanced astronomical knowledge inherited by the tribe, descriptions, and comparative belief systems with ancient civilizations.

Key Points:

  • Temple’s argument about the Dogon people’s knowledge of extraterrestrial visitation
  • Citing advanced astronomical knowledge and comparative belief systems

Important People:

  • Robert K. G. Temple
  • Marcel Griaule
  • Germaine Dieterlen

Locations:

  • Mali

UFO Religions ðŸ”—

Various new religious movements, including some branches of Theosophy, Scientology, RaÃ«lism, Aetherius Society, and Heaven’s Gate, believe in ancient and present-day contact with extraterrestrial intelligence. Many of these faiths see both ancient scriptures and recent revelations as connected with the action of aliens from other planetary systems.

Key Points:

  • Belief in ancient and present-day contact with extraterrestrial intelligence
  • Connection between ancient scriptures and alien actions

Organizations:

  • Theosophy
  • Scientology
  • RaÃ«lism
  • Aetherius Society
  • Heaven’s Gate

Claims of Proponents ðŸ”—

Scientists generally view the ancient astronaut hypothesis as unjustified and unnecessary, as the “mysteries” cited as evidence can be explained without invoking ancient astronauts.

Key Points:

  • Scientific consensus against the ancient astronaut hypothesis
  • Unnecessary nature of the hypothesis

Ancient Religious Texts ðŸ”—

Proponents cite ancient mythologies, interpreting creation myths of gods descending from the heavens as representations of alien visitors. They draw an analogy to modern cargo cults, where isolated cultures believe Western ships and cargo are sent from the gods.

Key Points:

  • Interpretation of ancient creation myths as alien visits
  • Analogy to modern cargo cults

Ramayana ðŸ”—

In Hindu mythology, gods and their avatars travel in flying vehicles called Vimana. The Ramayana contains mentions of these flying objects. Erich von DÃ¤niken suggests that the vimanas were “space vehicles.”

Key Points:

  • Mentions of flying vehicles (Vimana) in the Ramayana
  • Von DÃ¤niken’s interpretation of vimanas as space vehicles

Locations:

  • Ayodhya
  • Sri Lanka

The Bible ðŸ”—

Book of Genesis and Book of Enoch ðŸ”—

The Book of Genesis mentions the “sons of God” marrying human women and the Nephilim. The Book of Enoch expands on this, describing the “sons of God” as angels who descended to Earth to breed with humans. Some ancient astronaut proponents argue that this is a historical account of extraterrestrials visiting Earth, called Watchers, who made contact with humans, cross-bred with human females, and shared knowledge with them.

Key Points:

  • Interpretation of Genesis and Enoch as accounts of extraterrestrial contact
  • Watchers as extraterrestrials who cross-bred with humans
  • Nephilim as half-human-half-extraterrestrial hybrids
Book of ðŸ”—

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_astronauts

item.title: The Roswell Incident (1980 book)
item.description:
The Roswell Incident (1980 book) ðŸ”—

This entry details the 1980 book The Roswell Incident by Charles Berlitz and William Moore, which significantly contributed to popularizing the Roswell incident.

Background ðŸ”—

This section provides context for the Roswell incident, focusing on the events of 1947 and the renewed interest in the story in the late 1970s.

Events of 1947 ðŸ”—

This subsection outlines the initial reports of the Roswell incident during the “flying disc craze” of 1947, Kenneth Arnold’s sighting, the Roswell Army Air Field’s initial press release about recovering a crashed disc, and the subsequent retraction stating it was a weather balloon.

Roswell revisited ðŸ”—

This subsection explains how the Roswell story gained traction again in 1978 when retired lieutenant colonel Jesse Marcel claimed in an interview with ufologist Stanton Friedman that the debris he recovered was extraterrestrial.

Authors ðŸ”—

This section provides background information on the authors of the book, Charles Berlitz and William Moore. It mentions Berlitz’s previous success with The Bermuda Triangle and their collaboration on The Philadelphia Experiment: Project Invisibility.

Contents ðŸ”—

This section summarizes the book’s central argument: that an extraterrestrial craft crashed in New Mexico while observing nuclear weapons activity, and the US government engaged in a cover-up. It highlights accounts of debris described as “nothing made on this earth” and mentions witnesses like Bill Brazel, Floyd Proctor, and Walt Whitman Jr. The section also notes the book’s introduction of the idea that the debris shown in photos with Marcel was substituted as part of the cover-up. It also mentions the claim that the military sought to discredit the growing interest in flying saucers. The section also notes that the authors claimed to have interviewed over 90 witnesses, but only a fraction of those accounts appear in the book. The section also notes that the book elevated Marcel’s narrative above that of Cavitt, whose description of the debris contradicted Marcel.

Alien bodies ðŸ”—

This section details the book’s introduction of the story about Barney Barnett and archaeology students encountering wreckage and “alien bodies” on the Plains of San Agustin. It also mentions the conflation of the Roswell incident with the Aztec, New Mexico, UFO incident, a hoaxed flying saucer crash promoted by Frank Scully.

Reception ðŸ”—

This section discusses the reception of the book, noting that critics deemed it “a collection of wild hearsay” and that it “did not make the commercial impact its authors hoped.” It also mentions accusations against Moore regarding the Majestic 12 documents.

Aftermath ðŸ”—

This section mentions Moore’s admission at a 1989 MUFON conference that he had engaged in “disinformation” activities against Paul Bennewitz on behalf of the Air Force Office of Special Investigations.

Modern views ðŸ”—

This section references the 1993 inquiry by the General Accounting Office in response to US congressman Steven Schiff, which led to a 1994 Air Force report concluding that the recovered material was likely debris from Project Mogul, a military surveillance program using high-altitude balloons.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Roswell_Incident_(1980_book)

item.title: Dover Demon
item.description:
Dover Demon ðŸ”—

The Dover Demon is a creature reportedly sighted in Dover, Massachusetts, in April 1977.

Sightings ðŸ”—

This section details the reported sightings of the Dover Demon in April 1977. William “Bill” Bartlett, John Baxter, and Abby Brabham, all teenagers at the time, independently reported seeing a strange creature. Bartlett described it as about 4 feet tall with glowing orange eyes and no nose or mouth, with a watermelon-shaped head. Baxter reported a similar sighting on Miller Hill Road, and Brabham claimed to have seen the creature the following night on Springdale Avenue. The teenagers drew sketches of the creature, with Bartlett swearing on a stack of Bibles to the accuracy of his drawing. The locations of the sightings, when plotted on a map, formed a straight line over 2 miles. The sightings became public in May, and a local investigator noted similarities to the creatures in the Kellyâ€“Hopkinsville encounter. The Mutual UFO Network also investigated the sightings.

Possible explanations ðŸ”—

This section explores potential explanations for the Dover Demon sightings. One suggestion is that the creature was a foal or a moose calf. Skeptic Joe Nickell proposes that the creature was likely a snowy owl, citing its size and plumage, which could reflect yellow headlights. The “long spindly arms” could be the partially opened wings of the owl. Police suggested the sightings were a school vacation hoax. Ben Radford suggests the sightings may have been influenced by the release of Star Wars and Close Encounters of the Third Kind in 1977.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section outlines the Dover Demon’s appearances in popular culture. It was featured in an episode of the American horror television series Lost Tapes on Animal Planet in 2009. The Dover Demon appears as a character in the comic book series Proof, where it can see into the future, and in The Perhapanauts. It also made appearances in The Pound: Ghouls Night Out and Hack/Slash: Entry Wound. A Dover Demon appears in the webcomic Gunnerkrigg Court. In the manga series Dandadan, an alien known as Dover Demon takes the form of a bipedal crustacean-like alien.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dover_Demon
